docs.lead_paragraph: When pharmaceutical companies recruit sick people for studies of experimental drugs, what are the companies' obligations to the patients? And once people sign up, accepting risk but hoping for benefit, receiving free medical care and drugs, what do they owe to science, to future patients who may be helped by the research and to the company that may profit from it? Last year, Gail Ogden, 55, of Westmoreland, Kan., confronted those questions firsthand when her discovery that she had chronic hepatitis C, a viral disease of the liver, led her into the maze of modern experimental medicine.

headline.main: Patient or Guinea Pig? Dilemma of Clinical Trials

docs.abstract: Clinical trials for Rebetron, Schering-Plough's treatment for hepatitis C, illustrate the ethical questions that arise in tests of experimental drugs, including what obligations the pharmaceutical companies have to the patients they recruit and what obligations those patients have to science, to future patients who may be helped by research and to the company that may profit from it; Gail Ogden, who is three months into the 48-week trial, is very unhappy that data on her viral load is being withheld from her and her doctor; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: When a recruiter offered her a job as a research specialist at a rapidly growing medical company, Kimberly Belknap grabbed it and moved here from Grand Rapids, Mich., to get herself, as she put it, on a more lucrative career path. The new job, auditing doctors who test new drugs for pharmaceutical companies, pays nearly $60,000 a year. Ms. Belknap earned that much in Grand Rapids, but only by holding two jobs, and the long hours were getting to her. So was the lack of opportunity. As a 36-year-old physiologist, she had already risen, in her main job, to research coordinator at a local hospital.

docs.lead_paragraph: A scientist who helped to develop Redux, one of two weight-loss drugs taken off the market in 1997 after they were linked to heart damage, is now suggesting that the problems were not due to Redux alone, but rather to its being combined with other drugs that had unrecognized effects. The scientist, Dr. Richard Wurtman, director of the Clinical Research Center at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, said that his investigation into Redux had led him to believe that phentermine, a prescription diet drug that was taken with Redux but is still on the market, might be unsafe if taken together with the antidepressant Prozac or similar drugs. This risk, he said, might also exist with some over-the-counter cold medicines and weight-loss pills.

docs.lead_paragraph: Shortly after 9 A.M., Pamela Carlo arrived at the tiny, nondescript clinic in Chinatown for her daily deliverance. It was a cool day, with a packed gray sky. The tang of fish was in the air. She displayed her ID card at the check-in window, consulted the blackboard to see who had to give a urine sample (she didn't), then waited on the scuffed linoleum floor until her name finally crackled over the loudspeaker.

docs.lead_paragraph: Because of a growing chorus of concern that a major AIDS fund-raising event was encouraging illegal drug use and unsafe sex, organizers of the popular annual gay party on Fire Island announced yesterday that they were abandoning the event. For the last decade and a half, the gathering, known as the Morning Party, has been a poignant remembrance of those who have died of AIDS as well as an important fund-raiser for its sponsor, Gay Men's Health Crisis. But recently, the Morning Party, a swank social event held in the summer, has become something else: a cause for anger between G.M.H.C., perhaps the nation's leading AIDS service organization, and some gay critics who say the party has veered out of control.

headline.main: Gay Charity Cites Drug Use In Canceling a Fund-Raiser
